awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Growth of the Tibetan Plateau and Eastern Asia Climate: Clues to Understanding the Hydrological Cycle
awd_abstract_narration:
For fifty years, the Tibetan Plateau has been recognized as the largest topographic feature that perturbs atmospheric circulation.  It serves as an ideal field laboratory for understanding the geodynamic processes that build high terrain.  Accordingly, the growth of the plateau should have altered atmospheric circulation and therefore written an evolving paleoclimatic signature not only on eastern Asian regional climates, but on global climate as well.  Despite many recent studies, we still do not know precisely when the Tibetan Plateau reached its current dimensions and how it perturbs atmospheric circulation.  This project brings together geodynamicists, atmospheric scientists, and paleoclimatologists in a multidisciplinary study of the when and the how.

One of the major goals of the project is to quantify the extent to which Tibet has grown by crustal thickening, by thrust faulting and folding, by flow within the crust that redistributes material there, or by replacement of cold mantle lithosphere with hotter material (all in a state of isostatic equilibrium). Such quantification will take big steps toward the understanding of how high plateaus are built and how continental lithosphere deforms, topics at the forefront of geodynamics. 

Determining how Tibet has grown will require determining when crustal shortening and thickening occurred, using basic field methods and modern laboratory techniques, and quantifying paleoaltitudes with new isotopic tools. Applying such paleoaltimetric techniques, however, requires an understanding not only of how the atmosphere transports isotopes, but how the evolving high terrain affected surface temperatures at times in the past. Even if the project?s focus were solely on how Tibet has grown, a meteorological component of the study, focused particularly on eastern Asia?s hydrological cycle, would be necessary. 

Most continental paleoclimatic indicators are thought to be more sensitive to precipitation than to temperature, and among the unknowns of future climate, the hydrological cycle stands out.  Accordingly, a major focus will be on understanding how high terrain like Tibet affects the hydrological cycle of eastern Asia, and China in particular. These studies will focus on: (1) how the plateau, as both a topographic obstacle and a sink for solar radiation, affects atmospheric circulation; (2) how the atmosphere transports stable isotopes (ä18O and äD); (3) how it affects mid-latitude climate variability, including how, via lee cyclogenesis, it lofts and transports dust, and (4) how vegetation feeds back on atmospheric circulation and the hydrological cycle.  As links from geologic processes occurring at multi-Myr time scales to those on human time scales, the Principal Investigators plan studies that specifically examine paleoprecipitation over the past few hundred thousand years, using both loess deposition and speleothems that quantify paleoclimate.

por.por_cntn:
At an average elevation of 5 km, the Tibetan Plateau has a profound influence on the regional climate and hydrological cycle of Asia. For example, the vast inland Gobi and Taklimakan deserts owe their aridity to the Plateau’s topographic barriers to moisture that would normally be able to penetrate the interior of Asia in the absence of the Plateau. This project is focused on understanding the surface uplift history of the northern part of the Tibetan Plateau, adjacent to these deserts and the resultant aridification of the region north of Tibet to shed light on the tectonic processes that modulate the climate of Asia.

One of the major results from the project has provided insights into the hydrologic processes operating within the Tibetan Plateau that enable moisture to be transported across the plateau while conditions remain extremely arid north of the plateau. Through study of the stable isotope composition of streams and rivers across Tibet, as well as the trajectories of air masses associated with rainfall events, we have been able to model the isotopic evolution of water vapor across Tibet to learn that the wet climate on the Plateau is sustained by recycling of surface water. In other words, surface waters are re-evaporated over multiple cycles to sustain the vapor content of the atmosphere over Tibet. These results, along with our ongoing work to calibrate a method for measuring the surface temperature of the Plateau, will enable researchers to develop more reliable records of the surface uplift history of Tibet to provide constraints on how the Plateau has modulated the regional climate over time. Another major outcome of this project is the study of the paleoclimate of the Qaidam Basin immediately north of Tibet. Stable isotopes of carbonate sediment in lake deposits in this hyperarid region indicate that the onset of hyperaridity was at ~3 million years ago. The establishment of the arid conditions that we observe today are either related to the onset of glaciations of the northern hemisphere, which occurred at the same time, or the surface uplift of Tibet. Our study of complementary records of atmospheric dust (derived from deserts) deposited in the loess plateau, has revealed that zircons in loess were derived from northern Tibet and Qaidam basin. In comparison to most dust storm events that generate dust much further north, these results indicate that during glacial times, loess was sourced from much further south than it is today. This significant switch in atmospheric circulation is also recorded by fossilized wind erosion features (yardangs and dunes) preserved in Qaidam basin and across parts of northern Tibet. The pronounced differences in dust sources indicate that there may be significantly different atmospheric circulation in Asia between glacial and interglacial times that resulted in a large southward shift in the jet stream when glacial conditions persisted. Future research focused on the question of the effects of tectonics versus glaciation on the climate of the Asian interior will shed light on how future warming of global climate might affect these desert regions. For example, in the most simplistic view, if cooling of climate during the onset of northern hemisphere glaciation was the cause of aridification, then a reasonable hypothesis is that global warming should lead to wetter conditions north of the Plateau. If, however, the surface uplift of Tibet was responsible for the extremely arid conditions that we observe today, then the climate may become drier under global warming scenarios as some climate models predict.

This project has supported the education and training of young scientists, including three PhD students and a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Rochester.
